{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3607914,"name":"Nolan Hergert","username":"nhergert","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nhergert/{size}/162905_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T05:22:17.675Z","cooked":"

We are trying to revive our robot from last year while not converting our codebase to 2025 WPILib or updating our motors. I am on WPIib 2024. One issue is that it is refusing to download AdvantageKit dependencies from 2024.

I made sure to have the same username and password as expected in the build.gradle file. Here is our code. FRC_2024/vendordeps/AdvantageKit.json at main · AEMBOT/FRC_2024 · GitHub

Thanks!


Could not determine the dependencies of task ':jar'.

I am definitely not sure. But I don’t understand why “Unauthorized” is the error and in the 21st century, they can’t be stored for all of one additional year?

Jack in the Bot’s 2024 codebase also fails with the same errors. (with 3.2.0 AdvantageKit lib version)

One issue that could be causing unauthorized is:

In your build.gradle you could be using their 2024 username and password for their maven repositories when they have possibly updated it to a 2025 username and password. Double check their documentation and make sure your credentials are right.

Is there by chance a way to make your build.gradle up to date to 2025 paradigm whilst leaving your vendordep a 2024 version? If so you could try that next.

Looks like the user/pass did not change between 2024 and 2025. I copy the latest one to the 2024 repo and git detects no changes.

I’m not sure what you mean by upgrading build.gradle to 2025 paradigm.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-04-30T05:47:47.928Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":18.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500926,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-2024-dependencies-wont-download","display_username":"Nolan Hergert","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56270,"username":"v0ncent","name":"Vincent Banks","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/v0ncent/{size}/258352_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-2024-dependencies-wont-download/500926/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3607922,"name":"Vincent Banks","username":"v0ncent","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/v0ncent/{size}/258352_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T05:49:01.098Z","cooked":"

So I’m asking if it’s possible that they have updated how you need to write your build.gradle between 2024 → 2025 and that might be causing your issues.

Compiling errors like this are usually due to something in your build.gradle not being up to parr.

So check their latest docs

So it might be possible to change your build.gradle to authorize to their maven repositories whilst using an older version.

Because it’s entirely possible that something changed maven-side between 2024 - 2025 that needs to be accounted for in order to authorize to their repositories

Correct. No issues with the 2025 repo, and it looks like it is redownloading the dependencies if I make a new clone of it.

I would like to try deleting the cached vendordeps, but I can’t quite find where they are located.

Honest opinion, just scorched earth and delete your entire build folder that gets generated and rebuild your project

This has worked for me before

I cloned Jack in the Bot’s (2910) 2024 repo from scratch and had the same errors.

While I will try with the new build.gradle file mentioned, I wish to highlight the broader problem, which is that for some reason, these particular dependencies (AdvantageKit, PathPlannerLib) clean up their maven build urls much quicker than seems necessary, even though other dependencies like WPILib still keep old versions.

EDIT: No change with fresh 2024 repo and new build.gradle file.

Ok I just got home and to my pc and I was able to compare 2024 AKit Json to 2025 Akit json. Looks like group ids have changed between them:

2025 Version:

  "javaDependencies": [
    {
      "groupId": "org.littletonrobotics.akit",
      "artifactId": "akit-java",
      "version": "4.0.0"
    }
  ]

2024 Version:

"javaDependencies": [
    {
      "groupId": "org.littletonrobotics.akit.junction",
      "artifactId": "wpilib-shim",
      "version": "3.1.1"
    },
    {
      "groupId": "org.littletonrobotics.akit.junction",
      "artifactId": "junction-core",
      "version": "3.1.1"
    },
    {
      "groupId": "org.littletonrobotics.akit.conduit",
      "artifactId": "conduit-api",
      "version": "3.1.1"
    }
  ]

Try changing up your json with the 2025 version

Might be worth using the entire 2025 version of their json and replacing the version to the latest 2024 version / one you are wanting

TLDR: We just updated the documentation to address this issue. Try following the instructions in the “Legacy Projects” section below:

docs.advantagekit.org

Installation | AdvantageKit

New Projects

The reason for this issue is that we switched Maven hosting in 2025 from GitHub Packages to WPILib’s Artifactory server. GitHub Packages required authentication via a token (which we provided in the installation instructions). This was a fragile system, which is why we stopped using it this year; the new repository does not require authentication. After we already switched to the new system, a user inadvertently caused the old token to be revoked and broke old builds that relied on it (again, this is why we stopped using GitHub Packages in the first place).

To address the issue, we’ve now published the old versions of AdvantageKit to the new Maven repository. The instructions above explain how to switch your build to use the new repository, which will be much more stable.

nhergert:

these particular dependencies (AdvantageKit, PathPlannerLib) clean up their maven build urls much quicker than seems necessary

I can’t comment on PathPlanner, but we have never deleted old versions of AdvantageKit from our Maven repository. You can still access every version of AdvantageKit via GitHub Packages (so long as you provide your own token), and as explained above they are now available via the new Artifactory repo as well.
